aNZSAx-y2.memHandModelNotes:
Also associated with caves and talus.

Originally, this model had Side Slopes only selected for landforms limiting the distribtution only to Side Slopes. This produced a highly restrictive model. I removed Side Slopes from the model. MJR 26 October 2007.

references.B98PET01NCGP: Petranka, J. W. 1998. Salamanders of the United States and Canada. Washington DC: Smithsonian Inst. Press.
references.B05MES02USGP: Meshaka, W.E., Jr. 2005. Plethodon dorsalis (Cope 1889), Northern Zigzag Salamander. In Lannoo (Ed.), Amphibian Declines. The Conservation Status of United States Species, University of California Press, Berkeley, CA. p. 802-803.
references.W14IUC99USGP: IUCN. 2014. The IUCN Red List of Threatened Species. Version 2014.1. http://www.iucnredlist.org. Downloaded March 2016.
references.B01MIN01USGP: Minton, S. A., Jr. 2001. Amphibians & reptiles of Indiana. Revised second edition. Indiana Academy of Science, Indianapolis.
references.B95WIL01NCGP: Wilson, L. A. 1995. The Land Manager's Guide to the amphibians and reptiles of the South. Chapel Hill, NC: The Nature Conservancy.
references.A79REI01USGP: Reinbold, S.C. 1979. Habitat comparisons of two sympatric salamander species of the genus Plethodon (Amphibia, Caudata, Plethodontidae). Journal of Herpetology 13:504-506.

references.B61SMI01NAUS: Smith, P. W. 1961. The amphibians and reptiles of Illinois. Illinois Natural History Survey 28:1-298.

habitat_description: Northern zigzag salamanders live under leaf litter, logs, rocks, and bark primarily in hardwood and mixed forests and rocky slopes (Thurow 1955, Minton 2001).  They require a moist habitat with abundant surface cover preferring rocky substrates allowing acces to deep underground passages (Smith 1961, Reinbold 1979, Petranka 1979, Petranka 1998).  They may sometimes be associated with the mouths of caves, talus slopes, shale banks or other moist rock outcrop areas (Wilson 1995).
